rComments: Kind and funny. As others mentioned, lectures are very repetitive with very little content. Rod will take one concept and talk about it for way too long. Assignments were not clear nor was the criteria for which they were graded. Important class for getting people to re-think disability but not well organized.

lectures are repetitive. vague assignment instructions. marks are seemingly assigned at random, there's no rubric. won't accept any views as valid except his own. constantly bashing science and medical professionals, so stay away if you're a science student. not approachable, good luck if you want him to clarify assignment instructions for you.

Rod is a nice man. He's also very comedic. However I did not enjoy his class. I found him to be extremely boring and repetative. Half the class would fall asleep during his lectures. His assignments are very vague and unclear. Myself among many other class mates felt our assignments were never good enough and yet never given any direction by him to

He is a great professor! He really wants to see his students do well and is always available to disscuss your papers with.  Also no final for this course or NEW 241, which I also took with him.  Overall great experience and def looking to take another course with him.

World's greatest professor! Extremely brilliant, kind- hearted,professional and particularly helpful. Highly organised and can be anyone's best friend. Very unpretentious and is a true inspiration and role model.He is very dedicated and engaging.Passionate in his work in encouraging and challenging students to rethink notions of ability and disabil

His lectures are extremely repetitive and boring for the most part. He has a very good critical approach to social constructions of normalcy and helps you think critically but there is no way I would have attended his classes if the participation mark didn't depend on my signature. This class is great if you don't wanna study at all and get an A.

Great professor! Challenges students to think outside the box. Enrolled in his class in first year, loved it and have studied under him every year since. One of the most brilliant, engaging, and helpful professors at U of T. Is not only a teacher but a friend to his students as well. No one could teach Disability Studies better.
His lectures are boring and repetitive. The course has potentional for wonderful discussion and debate which he denies with his lengthy lectures about very little. It is unfortunate.

Speaks with passion and conviction, and inspires the same in students. Emphasizes a concrete, real world approach with assignments so flexible that some students found them intimidating. He was friendly, approachable, and seemed at times to channel the spirit of Baloo from The Jungle Book.
